awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a High-throughput Flow Cytometry for Health Science Research and Training
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award supports the acquisition of a high performance, high-throughput, and multicolor fluorescence cell analyzer at Binghamton University.  The acquisition of this instrument will help Binghamton University investigators to perform research in developing new technologies for regenerative medicine, drug delivery, cancer early diagnosis, 3D bioprinting, muscular dystrophy associated multicellular lesions, cancer vaccine formulations for cancer immunotherapy, and high-throughput screening of anti-cancer agents. These studies will advance fields such as tissue engineering, pharmacology, regenerative medicine, cell biology, drug discovery, and protein sciences. This added research infrastructure will spur more collaborations in educational programs and will enhance a number of biological and health science courses. New courses and workshops will be developed to provide new education and training opportunities to both graduate and undergraduate students. Annual campus-wide open-house events will be held to reach out to K-12 students and local communities, especially to those from underrepresented groups. 

The multicolor fluorescence cell analyzer will be configured with five lasers covering wavelengths from UV to infrared for detecting 23 different colors simultaneously. Its high-throughput configuration will allow the automated completion of 96-well plate analysis within 15 minutes and with less than 0.5% sample carryover from one well to the next. The addition of these new capabilities will empower Binghamton University's investigators to pursue new research directions and to expand their research and education programs. Furthermore, the acquisition of the cell analyzer will foster Binghamton University's collaboration with hospitals and industries to accelerate the translation of health science discoveries into commercial products. The studies conducted through this project will offer new insights into fundamental understanding of biological systems, leading to the development of new technologies for improving human health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to acquire a high performance, high-throughput, and multicolor fluorescence cell analyzer to bring more advanced flow cytometric analysis capabilities to Binghamton University (BU) as part of its expansion plan for the campus Health Sciences Core Facility (HSCF). With the support of this grant, a ZE5 flow cytometer from Bio-Rad was purchased and installed in HSCF at BU. The cell analyzer is equipped with 5 lasers for 27 color analysis, capable of detecting up to 100,000 events per second. It is integrated with universal sample loader with agitation and temperature control for 5 mL tubes, 96- and 384-well plate.

The addition of these new capabilities to HSCF empowers BU’s investigators with more advanced tools of cellular analysis, allowing them to pursue new directions of research and expand their research and educational programs. The instrument has been continuously maintained in operational condition and running on a regular basis. All trainings and service requests have been successfully accommodated since the installation of the instrument. Workshops/trainings have been held to offer new researchers with hands-on training in using the instrument. In addition, the manager of Core Facility provides one-on-one training on a need basis.

Intellectual Merit:

The instrument has served research groups from the Department of Biomedical Engineering, Chemistry Department, Biological Sciences Department, and Pharmaceutical Sciences Department in three Colleges (Watson College of Engineering and Applied Science, Harpur College of Arts and Sciences, and School of Pharmacy) since it was installed at the HSCF. The research fields supported by the instrument include cancer research, stem cell biology, tissue engineering, antibody discovery, drug discovery, bacteria biology, etc. The instrument has become indispensable for many laboratories. The instrument helped faculty and students to acquire preliminary research data for grant applications. As a result, a number of faculty have secured grants from NIH and NSF. The instrument also helped researchers to acquire crucial data for publishing papers in high impact journals. Overall, the flow cytometer has become an essential research infrastructure at BU, which supports many cutting-edge biomedical and interdisciplinary fundamental research on campus. In addition, the instrument has been used for teaching and exposing students to advanced analytical tools in cell and molecular engineering.

Broader Impacts:

The flow cytometer has been an essential component of BU’s research infrastructure. It contributes significantly to training graduate and undergraduate researchers in cutting-edge research and career development. Training components related to the cell analyzer and its vital role for solving biomedical engineering and science problems have been implemented to course lectures to provide students in depth knowledge and training. The instrument will continue serving the scientific community at BU for research and training after the NSF grant support ends through hands-on training and classroom demonstrations.


Last Modified: 01/10/2023
Modified by: Sha Jin
